This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, with which she intends to buy more items for the general store so that she can continue to save up for the future improvement of her business.

 Belinda B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Marco Rosario

texts.es: Cliente es soltero vive en la casa de sus padres tiene 39 años de edad  no tiene carga familiar tiene su auto propio que lo trabaja para la empresa de colectivos de Santiago solicita el crédito para mantenimiento y arreglos de su auto y actualizar su licencia de conducir. Para así poder trabajar tiene grandes deseos de superación trabaja junto con su padre quien lo apoya moralmente.
texts.en: Marco is single and lives with his parents.  He is 39 years old and does not have any dependents.  He owns a car and works for the Santiago taxi company.  Marco is requesting this loan for maintenance and repairs on his car and to renew his driver's license so that he can continue working.  He has big dreams for personal development. He works with his father who gives him moral support.

loans.use: For maintenance and repairs on his car

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Julio Eduardo

texts.es: Solicitante, tiene 29 años, es soltero, vive en casa familiar,  se dedica al negocio hace mas de 2 años,  tiene la meta de tener mas unidades de transporte, y cumplir con sus sueños y objetivos, solicita credito para capital de trabajo ya que piensa invertir en el negocio.
texts.en: Julio is 29 years old, single, and lives with his family.  He has dedicated himself to his transportation business for more than two years.  He would like to increase the number of vehicles he owns.  To reach his dreams and goals, he is requesting this loan, which he will use for working capital.  He will invest the funds in his business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Ma. Glenda

texts.en:
Ma.Glenda S. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Canduman, Compostela, Cebu City. She earns her living by operating a general store and an auto repair shop. Her husband Francisco S., who is 30 years old, works as a mechanic to earn his living.  They have two children who are 2 and 3 years old. 

Ma.Glenda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 3 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma.Glenda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,700, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 4th loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, with which she intends to buy items for the general store to sell to her customers so that she can continue to save up for her children's education. 

Ma.Glenda S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

 About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock of items for general store

loans.name: Luis Jhonathan

texts.es: Luis es soltero tiene 21 años de edad vive en casa de su tia ubicada en la calle Santa Isabel el se inicio como chofer de manera dependiente aproximadamente tres años actualmente cuenta con dos mototaxis propias la cual una trabaja él de forma independiente y la otra da en alquiler el financiamiento otorgado sera destinado para el mantenimiento y reforzamiento de su dos mototaxis, se le otorga el financiamiento por contar con buenas referencias,voluntad y capacidad de pago.
texts.en: Luis is single and is 21 years old.  He lives in his aunt's home, located on Santa Isabel Street.  He began working as a driver, as an employee, about three years ago.  He now owns two motorcycle taxis. He uses one to work independently and rents out the other.  The financing he is granted will be used for maintenance and improvements on both of his motorcycle taxis.  He is receiving this financing because of his strong references and his will and ability to repay it.

loans.use: Maintenance of his motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg is 29 years old and lives with her son and grandmother in Songinohairhan district, Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her son attends a local primary school. They live in a house which they own and they have a decent standard of living. She finished a vocational school with a bachelor's degree as a hair stylist and beautician and began operating a hair salon in 2001. Her hair salon is located on the outskirts of the city where there are not many salons. Therefore, she has many regular customers in her area. 

She is planning to expand her hair salon to include beauty services. She is a hard-working and initiative person who says, " I would like to provide hairdressing and beauty services to the residents of this semi-urban area at a reasonable price." She is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to enlarge her current salon and purchase some equipment in order to operate a beauty service, too.

loans.use: To enlarge her current salon

loans.name: Rosenda

texts.en:
Rosenda D. is a single woman who lives in Brgy. Tan-awan, Oslob, Cebu.  She earns her living by operating fish vending and livestock businesses. Rosenda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosenda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,400, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 13th loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000, which she intends to use for additional capital for the business so that she can continue to save up for future house repair. Rosenda D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to fund the operations of fish selling business

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en:
Tuya, 52, is married and lives with her husband and daughter in Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Their daughter attends a local school; her husband is disabled due to a car accident. They live in a house on the outskirts of the city and they have a decent standard of living. 

Tuya started a public transportation business in 2006. She made an agreement with a bus company to get the bus by leasing it and making payments from her profit. Now she owns the bus as she has finished the payments recently. By owning the bus, she only pays taxes and the driver's salary while all the income directly goes to her. She is planning to have her own garage in the near future. 

Tuya is a polite and honest person who says, "I wish to build a better life and help my daughter to finish university by working hard." Tuya is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to buy spare parts and cover maintenance costs for her bus.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Phann

texts.en:
Phann T. is a 38-year-old married man who earns his daily living by driving a motor taxi in Siem Reap province. He normally generates a profit on average of $5 each day. Phann T. has a life partner in his wife, a tailor in Phnom Penh City, earning a profit around $5 per day, which she shares with Phann T. for daily expenses. This couple has two children; both of them are studying in a local school. 

Unfortunately, their existing motorbike has often broken down during use. Because of that, Phann T. has decided to seek a loan of $1200 from Kiva, which he will use to change the broken motorcycle. With the rest of the funds, he will support his wife's business.

loans.use: To change their broken motorcycle and support his wife's business

loans.name: Bayarmaa

texts.en:
Bayarmaa is 41 years old and lives with her three daughters in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. Her older daughter studies at a medical university, her second daughter works as a salesperson at a department store, and the youngest daughter goes to kindergarten.

 In 1997 Bayarmaa began selling meat at a rented stall at a local food market. She has been operating her business constantly and has gained a lot of experience. She sells also dairy products in the summer in addition to meat. Her current working capital exceeds 600,000 MNT. Bayarmaa is a hard-working person who says, "It was not easy to raise three children as a single mother until my daughters got old enough to help me. I would like to expand my business and help my daughters to start their own life without any difficulty." She is requesting a loan of 440,000 MNT to purchase more meat for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
John Richardson, Jr. said, “When it comes to the future, there are three kinds of people: those who let it happen, those who make it happen, and those who wonder what happened.” Definitely, our CCT* Community Partner Emily A. is one who falls among the second group. At 61, she makes her dreams happen. Emily reached only high school, but just like her fellow community partners, this simple educational background has not served as a major hindrance to her in becoming a good micro-entrepreneur. Emily is married to Jose; together, they brought up five children in Santa Clarissa, Tanza, Cavite.

Currently, Emily manages her own sari-sari (variety) store, as well as a computer shop. She has these businesses running a few steps from home, which makes it easier for her to keep an eye on their day-to-day operations. She does not hire any employees, managing to run both the shop and the store on her own. Monthly Emily earns around Php 11,280. 

In prudence Emily decided to borrow Php 20,000. She did so  primarily to help her grow her sari-sari store. She opted to purchase rice, assorted groceries, and soft drinks. Also, she plans to buy an additional computer for her computer shop and some computer software.

Emily takes it a personal challenge to keep going on with her business and unceasingly pray for its growth. Nevertheless, she knows that with the Lord by her side there is nothing to worry about. She intends to save her profits and invest in another business in preparation for the future of her family because for her, success is something you don’t simply wait for; you have to make it happen.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends their group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she has received.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: purchasing rice and groceries for her store

loans.name: Alberto

texts.en:
His is a life far from financial lack, but also his is the determination not to settle for anything less than the best God has in store for him. His name is Alberto G., 31. Having finished college, Alberto is off to a good start when it comes to business. He currently lives with Jeodalyn in Tanza, Cavite, along with their only child, who is not yet of school-going age. Like Alberto, Jeodalyn is into business.

Alberto runs his own computer shop near their home. He has been doing so for five years now without needing any help from hired employees or assistants. His business meets the huge demand of his community when it comes to internet access. Basically, he caters to the younger generation from the middle class, who need access to online sources for homework, projects, and entertainment. With this Alberto earns around Php 10,000 monthly.

To help him continue operation of his businesses, he is requesting a Php 11,000 loan. He will use the money to add to his savings and buy three additional monitors.  He knows this will greatly benefit his computer shop as this will enable him to cater to more customers.

The present condition of the Philippine economy is one challenge Alberto mentions. However, he believes that as an entrepreneur with good potential, he is able to overcome such a challenge and pursue his dream of putting up another computer shop. Of course, he would want his family to be the primary beneficiaries of his success. Alberto’s deep desire is to become stable not just in business, but also in his personal life.

As a CCT community partner, he faithfully attends to group's weekly fellowship* meeting where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he has received.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: purchasing computer monitors

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma P.'s main source of income comes from fattening pigs for sale. She is 50 years old, married and has three grown-up children. She is from the village of Sta. Lucia, Quirino, Isabela. Norma has been in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2008, Norma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Norma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to invest in expanding the business. Norma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This will be her sixth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Tum

texts.en: Mrs. Tum S. is a 42-year-old farmer in the province of Svay district, Phnom Penh City. She plants rice and some vegetable crops, which she sells to buyers when the produce is mature. She has a partner in her husband, who assists her in farming the crops. This couple has been married for years and they have six teenage children. Five of their children are single and the remaining one is married. Recently her farm has been outside of a watering system. Mrs. Tum S. will use her loan to buy a pumping machine for irrigation. She proposes using the remainder of loan to purchase a sack of fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy a pumping machine for irrigation and to purchase a sack of fertilizer.

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo D. C. is called Fred by his friends. At 43, he works as a persevering store owner and is a life partner to Thess and the father of two children.  Together, they live in Deroman, Tanza, Cavite. He seeks not only to be the best micro entrepreneur he can be but also to become the best dad to his children. As a breadwinner, he aims to generate more profit and save enough to become financially stable for the future of his kids, his utmost treasure. 

It is a challenge to him sustain his business capital, all the more when one problem arising is the health of his kids. Nevertheless, he holds on to the hope he has in the Lord, and believes that things are going to get better for his family. As a CCT community partner, he faithfully attends to the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God.

With the learning he gets from CCT, Fred knowingly runs his own sari-sari (variety) store to cater to the immediate needs of his fellow community members. The store is situated at home so he has easily managed it daily for three years now without any helpers. He is able to earn Php 10,640 monthly on average. To help him grow his business, he is applying for a loan of Php 8,000. He will use the loan to buy more soft drinks as well as groceries with which to fill his store shelves. He knows that with these products he will be able to make his store more profitable.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks and groceries to sell in a general store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more milk and dairy products.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Bun S. is a 48-year-old married man who resides in the province of Siem Reap. Bun S. earns his income by ferrying villagers and tourists across the river. He generates a profit of approximately $6 US each day to help support his family’s daily expenses. His wife assists him in the same business, as well as manages many duties at home. Bun S. has three children, all of whom are single. 

Bun S.'s ferry broke down while driving. He doesn’t have enough money to make repairs, so he is seeking a Kiva loan to fix his broken ferry.

loans.use: To repair his broken ferry

loans.name: Ailyn

texts.en:
Ailyn P. is from the village of Sta Lucia, Quirino, Isabela. She is 46 years old. Ailyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Ailyn owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Ailyn has been engaged in her business for over 18 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Ailyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ailyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ailyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Ailyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ton

texts.en: The woman shown in the picture is Ton S.. She is a cloth trader; she buys pieces of cloth from garment factories and then sells them to the people who turn it into other products to sell. In addition, she also takes some pieces of clothes to weave mats, and sells them for extra-income to help support her family with daily expenses. She is married to Chomnan, a 31-year-old local farmer. The couple have three young children who attend school. In order to improve her business, Ton S. would like to request a loan to buy more pieces of cloth to weave mats to sell.

loans.use: To buy more pieces of cloth to weave mats

loans.name: Garmaarinchen

texts.en: Garmaarinchen, 60, is married and lives with his wife in Uvurhangai province in Mongolia. His wife is retired and they live apart from their son, who is grown. In 2004, Garmaarinchen started a business trading animal hides. More recently, he bought a car and opened a taxi business. He is a hardworking and modest person, and is applying for this loan for 1,000,000 MNT to buy spare parts for the car that he uses as his taxi.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his taxi

loans.name: Linda's Group

texts.en:
Linda P. lives in the village of San Jose. She is 36 years old and leads an 11-person loan group, nine of whose members we see here, that is affiliated with ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Linda is married, has two school-aged children and makes a living by raising livestock. She has been in this line of work for more than five years and makes about 4,000 PHP when she sells one of her animals.

Last year, Linda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a  loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI and is applying for a new one, for 8,000 PHP, to invest in expanding her business. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to continue expanding her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand several small businesses

loans.name: Basilia

texts.en:
Basilia B. is 52 years old and a college graduate who lives in Dasmariñas, Cavite with her four children. Three of them are working, and the fourth is in high school.

Basilia earns a living making rugs, and devotes a good deal of time and energy to securing the right raw materials and picking the best markets in which to sell her goods. She now has four employees, runs her business out of her home, and earns about 10,000 PHP a month. She is committed to continue expanding her business and has applied for this loan, for PHP 19,000, to increase her output of rugs. Some day, she would also like to buy a car for her family to use. 

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends to the group's weekly fellowship* meetings where draws strength and inspiration from studying holy scripture.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather  to study scripture, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to expand a small rug-making company

loans.name: Altangerel

texts.en: Altangerel, 43, is married and lives with his wife and three children in Uvurhangai province in Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and have a good standard of living. All of his children attend school, and his wife works with him in the meat-trading business he started in 2005 and has since expanded into a food-selling business. He also supplements his income by raising livestock. He is a hardworking and modest person who says, "I want to have my own land and build a house in the near future". Altangerel is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to buy more meat to sell to his customers.

loans.use: To buy more meat

loans.name: Enhbold

texts.en: Enhbold, 32, lives with his wife and a son in Uvurhangai province in Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, which is set up in a friend's backyard. He makes a living running a carpentry business. In 2008, he began to making wood products in his yard and now turns out quite a bit of furniture and structural elements for gers. He is an honest and hardworking person who says, "I would like to make and sell more products in order to have my own land where I can build a house". He is requesting a loan of 500,000 MNT to buy more supplies and meet an increase in orders from his customers.

loans.use: To buy more supplies for a small business

loans.name: Phap

texts.en:
Phap S. is a sewing worker at a garment factory in Phnom Penh City. She has had experience in this sector for over one year, and has a formal salary every month. 

She has a life partner in her husband, who is a driver in the factory. The couple makes an average profit for their work of $8 US a day for use for the whole family. 

Presently, her husband is concerned because he wishes to buy a motorcycle (Tuk Tuk) for starting a motor taxi service besides his currently work for additional income. To motivate her husband, Phap S. has decided to request funds from Kiva. 

Phap S. has two young children who are enrolled in public school.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle (Tuk Tuk) for starting a motor taxi service for her husband

loans.name: Byambadorj

texts.en: Byambadorj, 60, is married and lives with his wife and two children in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They live in a winter house on land that they own. In 2007, he began to make wood products in his backyard. He has an electric saw and mostly makes structure parts for the Mongolian nomadic housing tents called ger. He also makes furniture when he receives orders from his customers. He is a hardworking and modest person who says, "I would like to have my own workshop for my carpentry business." Byambadorj is requesting a loan of 600,000 Mongolian tugriks to buy more wood and materials for his business.

loans.use: To buy more wood and materials

loans.name: Amia

texts.en:
Some people would love simplicity in life. Amia D. A., 64, would want a simple life, too. Amia only reached elementary school, but she did not allow her life to end simpler than that. She is married to Jaime, and together they raise eight children in their home in Dasmarinas, Cavite.

One strategy Amia employed to fight the curse of a poor educational background is to run her own sari-sari (variety) store near their home. The training and fellowship she experiences in CCT* as a Community Partner enabled her to set it up and continually operate it. With this, she is able to earn around 7,300 Philippines pesos (Php) per month.

Simple as it is, her sari-sari store needs leveling up. Amia is requesting a Php15,000 loan. She needs this money to buy new products to fill her store shelves. Also, she has to replenish her stock of salable items such as noodles and coffee sachets.

Even a simple life is not devoid of struggles, and Amia has her share of those. However, she sees them not worth mentioning. Instead, she speaks of her dream of becoming prosperous and having their own family car. She wants to be assured of her family being well off toward a good future.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly bA.. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: The purchase of new products for her store

loans.name: Abdimalik's Group

texts.en:
Abdimalik A., age 45, is a member of this group. He is a resident of Nookat, a small village in the south of Kyrgyzstan, near Osh. He and his wife are bringing up four sons, the eldest of whom went to work in Russia. The younger three are students. In order to earn money to cover family expenses, Abdimalik works as a driver and his wife sells children's clothing at market. With the money received from the loan, the family wants to purchase more clothes to offer for sale in order to increase the turnover of the business. In the near future, Abdimalik wants to finish the construction of the family's new house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line:
– People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), 
– Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and 
– Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 
MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase children clothing

loans.name: Yean

texts.en: Yean T. is a 31-year-old single woman who lives with her five single children in a small house in Kompong Chhnang province. She has been working a sewing worker since 2006, and has a formal salary of around $2.50 per day. She is a determined mother who tries all her best to feed her five kids. Now, her living condition is not comfortable as her house was in building process as she doesn’t have more money to buy more planks. To solve this problem, Yean T. would like to ask for her loan to purchase additional planks to finish in building.

loans.use: To purchase additional planks to finish in building.

loans.name: Barchinoi's Group

texts.en:
Barchinoi M., age 36, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Nookat, a small village near Osh. She and her husband are bring up three sons: the eldest is at school and the others are not yet. Barchinoi and her husband work at the school, and in order to earn additional money for the family budget they breed cattle. They have been breeding cattle for six years. With the money received from this loan, the family wants to purchase a cow in order to resell it at a higher price after fattening. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: 
– People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), 
– Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and 
– Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Khut's Group

texts.en:
This group is made up of three borrowers, all of whom live in the province of Kompong Tom. The group's leader, Khut M., age 45, is married and has five children, one of whom is employed as a garment factory worker. Khut M. makes a living by selling baskets. She and her husband currently buy raw materials to make baskets to sell at their home. They also buy baskets from other weavers at a reasonable price and resell them to gain extra profits. They have done this since 1980. Khut M. will be using her loan to buy more raw materials in order to make baskets to offer for sale.

The other two borrowers include Mr. S., who will be using his loan to buy baskets to offer for sale, and Mrs. N., who will use her loan to purchase wood materials in order to to mend her old house.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials in order to make baskets to offer for sale

loans.name: Phon

texts.en: Phon H., age 42, and her husband Ou Choeun, age 46, live in the province of Kompong Cham. For over ten years, they have earned their living by cultivating rice crops. Phon H. wants to plant a potato crop, but she doesn’t have funds to do so yet. In order to achieve her plan, Phon H. would like to ask for a Kiva loan in order to buy potato seeds for planting. She hopes to use the remainder of the funds to enlarge her house. The couple is blessed with three children, two of whom earn a living by planting various crops on their own farmland, and the youngest attends the local school.

loans.use: To buy potato seeds for planting. She hopes to use the remainder of the funds to enlarge her house.

loans.name: Adyajav

texts.en:
Adyajav is 37 years old and lives with her husband and 2 children. They live in ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Ulaanbaatar- the Mongolian capital city. Her two sons attend local secondary school. Her husband delivers stationary to people who operate stalls in the market. Adyajav has been operating a taxi business for 7 years and has gained much experience. She is planning to expand her business and says, "I have a dream to have my own grocery store one day to ensure my children’s future life." 

This is Adyajav's fourth loan through Credit Mongol. Adyajav’s youngest son has an eyesight problem. She needs to send her son to have eye surgery in India. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to increase her business capital.

loans.use: To increase business capital

loans.name: Nget

texts.en: Nget S. has spent his life cultivating crops in the province of Kompong Cham. This is a skill he learned as a young man from his grandparents. Nget S. is married and has two school-aged children. His wife frequently works in the field alongside him. Nget S. will be using his loan to add to his personal savings, which, once he has enough, he plans to use in order to buy a plot of his neighbor’s farmland near his house, which is a good location for farming. He will then rent out this land to farmers for a fee. The loan will thus provide him with an additional new asset. The rest of the fund will be used to buy peanut seeds for planting.

loans.use: To apply toward his savings fun to buy a plot of farmland, and to purchase peanut seeds for planting.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea V., age 33, is a resident of Kompong Tom Province, where she operates a small business raising a few pigs for income. Her husband works as a hired farmhand. They have one small child. Chea V. is a hard-working woman who believes time is money - she works hard in order to earn money to ensure that the family can have a better life. Chea V. is applying for a loan to purchase additional feed and piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase additional feed and piglets to raise.

loans.name: Khath

texts.en: Khath K., age 54, sells firewood for a living. He earns a profit of around $1.40 per day. His wife is a local farmer in Baray district, Kompong Tom province. They are blessed with five children, three of whom are married. The two of them are employed in different jobs in order to provide the family with daily revenue. Presently, Khath K. uses a cart for transporting his products, but it is really hard for him push when it contains a large amount of firewood. To preserve his energy, Khath K. would like to buy a cow to pull his cart. This will help to alleviate the physical strain of running his business.

loans.use: To buy a cow in order to pull his firewood cart

loans.name: Julius Kinyua

texts.en:
Julius has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last four years. He is 34 years old, married to Jane Gathoni and they have one child.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers. This will be his third loan. He plans to use the loan amount to clear paying for land he has purchased.

In the future, Julius hopes to start dairy farming on the piece of land he just bought.

loans.use: To pay off purchased land

loans.name: Wallen

texts.en:
Life is not all about fattening one’s wallet: it is also about fattening one’s heart with love. Even as Wallen O., age 33, works hard to become a successful micro-entrepreneur, she also strives to make sure her family receives the same level of attention from her. Wallen, a college graduate, is a Community Partner in CCT*, a wife to her husband Armando, and a mother to two elementary students. Together the family resides in Dasmarinas, Cavite.

Wallen’s primary business is to buy and sell soft drinks. She also breeds pigs and sells them to interested buyers in her community, many of whom are her acquaintances and friends. She raises the pigs in her back yard and sells them through business connections. Through these endeavors, she earns around Php 8,100 a month.

Wallen has requested a loan of Php 12,000, as this is necessary to help her grow her business. She will use this in order to buy sacks of feed for her pigs’ daily consumption and to be able to keep up with the maintenance of her pig pens, as this is necessary to breed healthy pigs. 

Deeply aspiring to become a successful entrepreneur, Wallen is ready to face whatever challenges lie ahead of her. With the business learning she has gained from CCT and the guidance she receives from God’s Word, Wallen is sure to fatten up her business as well as her family with love and a good future.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To invest in her pig breeding business

loans.name: Um

texts.en:
Um S., age 38, makes a living by selling fish and pork in and around Kompong Tom province. Um S. sells fish that she buys from fishermen and pork from her husband's butcher business. She currently earns an average of US $3 a day, and she has been running her business for years. Her husband is 34 years old and is a local butcher. 

Um S. is the mother of three teenage children who are no longer in school. All of her children are working at various occupations, and they each contribute some of their incomes to help the family meet its daily expenses. 

Um S.’s employed son has been paying money for taxis to get to work because he doesn't own a vehicle. To solve this problem, Um S. is applying for a loan to purchase a used motorcycle, which will allow her son to commute to his work location.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle for her son in order to provide transportation for him to get to his work location.

loans.name: Alexei

texts.en:
Alexei is a farmer who grows early spring vegetables in Kamenka, where he lives. Alexei and his wife have two daughters. He owns two land lots and five big arch greenhouses. He started this business five years ago and has invested 100,000 Grivnyas in this business. His expenses on seeds and polyethylene film amount to 30,000 Grivnyas every year. 

Alexei is seeking a loan of 15,000 Grivnyas to purchase seeds, soil, and polyethylene film. He is hoping to have good harvest and receive additional income to be re-invested in the construction of new arch greenhouses on his property in the future.

loans.use: To purchase polyethylene film, seeds, and fertilizers for his farming business

loans.name: Andrei

texts.en:
Andrei lives and works in Kamenka, which is a predominantly agricultural region of Ukraine. Andrei owns three large greenhouses and a separate one for seedlings. His farming business has been around for 15 years. He has invested 60,000 Grivnyas in this business. His annual expenses on seeds and polyethylene film amount to 35,000 Grivnyas. Andrei is married with two children. 

Andrei is requesting a 15,000 Grivnya loan to construct a new greenhouse and to purchase the film to cover it, as well as to reconstruct one of the three greenhouses he already has. One of Andrei’s plans for the future is to build an additional greenhouse and generate extra income.

loans.use: To construct a greenhouse and purchase polyethylene film

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more stock of assorted fruits and vegetables for sale

loans.name: Loida's Group

texts.en:
Loida C., age 34, is from the village of Maddarulug Sur. Loida is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Loida C.'s Group.

Loida is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Loida owns and operates a general store, where she sells a variety of different products to members of the local community. Loida has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Loida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. She eished to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Loida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Loida is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Loida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items in order to expand her product offerings

loans.name: Fabian

texts.en:
Fabian O. is 31 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. Fabian has a boutique, which he has run for five years. He also has a second business – a mobile business selling rope.
To help expand his business, Fabian has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes for resale. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Fabian hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. In the future, he hopes to build a residential house for his family to move into in order to reduce the expense of renting and add money into his business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith has been practicing mixed farming for the last ten years and employs three to five casual laborers. Her mixed farm produces vegetables, milk, and bananas, which are all sold locally. 

She has requested a loan of 62,400 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow and to buy a chuff cutter. The profits from the sale of milk will enable her to pay school fees for her two children, both of whom are enrolled in the local school. She would like to own at least three dairy cows and to buy another piece of land in the next five years. Her major challenges are cattle diseases and lack of proper markets for her products.

Faith is 43 years old and married with three children between the ages of 12 and 20.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow and to buy a chuff cutter

loans.name: Lonkishu Ole

texts.en:
Lonkishu Ole M. is 52 years old. He is a married father of 12 children. He has been farming for the last ten years. His farm is in a productive area which has proved to be good for wheat farming.

He learned about KADET LTD through a marketing campaign done by KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his first loan, which he plans to use preparing his wheat farm for the next planting season. Wheat normally does well in his area due to good climatic conditions. 


He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming, to increase his wheat production, and educate his children. His hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer and buy a bigger piece of land and build a plot. Lonkishu is a hard-working man who can do more if supported financially.

loans.use: To prepare his wheat farm for the next season of planting

loans.name: Tserenchimeg

texts.en:
Tserenchimeg is 33 years old, lives with her 2 children and her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They all live together in a one-bedroom studio apartment. Her two children, 5 and 13, attend kindergarten and local secondary school. Tserenchimeg has worked in a laundry service, named “Pegma”, as a hostess since 2005. Her husband Uranbaatar, 35, has operated a tire repair shop for the last three years. Tserenchimeg purchased a second-hand car by her savings. 

This is her second loan through Credit Mongol and she is one of our reliable customers. Tserenchimeg says "I am planning to open my own laundry service in the future.” Tserenchimeg is requesting a loan to purchase construction materials to fix her apartment.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials to fix her apartment

loans.name: Susan Wangari

texts.en:
Susan Wangari N. is 28 years old and married to James Maina. Together they have two children. Susan runs a clothes boutique in Lodwar town and has been in this business for four years. She makes a monthly income of KES 17,000.

This will be Susan's first loan from KADET LTD and she plans to use the entire loan to buy new clothes to sell. With the  income from this investment she plans to expand her business by buying more clothes for resale. 

In the future she wishes to become financially stable and to provide for her family's basic needs.

loans.use: To  buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Sros

texts.en: Mrs. Sros K. (pictured) and her husband, Mr. Poem Porng, live in a village in a suburb of Phnom Penh. They have two sons and three daughters. Sros runs a grocery store from her home. Her husband is a motor taxi driver. She is asking for a loan in the amount of $1,000 in order to repair and renovate the house where they live.

loans.use: To repair and renovate the family home.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Sophy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophy C. (pictured) and her husband, Mr. Nun Buo, have been married since 1982 and have five children. They live along National Road Number Six, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. Sophy and her husband sell mango. They buy it under contract from fellow villagers before harvest season and, when the mangoes are fully grown, they take them to sell at the local market. 

Sophy has received a previous loan through Kiva, and she is now requesting her second loan in the amount of $700, which will be used to purchase additional mango for to offer for resale.

loans.use: To purchase mango to offer for resale.

loans.name: Oem

texts.en: Oem S., age 21, is a mother blessed with a small child. She currently generates an income of approximately $2 per day by selling Khmer cake. Oem S.'s husband works in a private company as a sales representative. Oem S. is requesting this loan because she wishes to purchase a plot of farmland, which she will use for a farming business. This loan will thus provide her with a new additional asset.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to use for a farming business.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom T. (pictured) and her husband, Mr. Chheng Srey, have been married since 1972 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. Three are married and other three are in school. The family lives in a village across the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mom has been a weaver since she was young, while her husband is a farmer. He grows rice and vegetables. Mom is asking for her first loan of $1,100. She will use $800 of the loan to purchase weaving materials for her weaving business and another $300 to buy a water-pumping machine for her husband's business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business and to buy a water-pumping machine for her husband's business

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy N. (pictured) lives on an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. She has four young children, three sons and one daughter. 

Chanthy is a silk weaver, but she has just delivered a baby so she has stopped the weaving business for a while and has started a new business selling grocery items from her home. Her husband is a driver. 

Chanthy is requesting her second Kiva loan in the amount of $500 in order to provide capital for her mother’s farming business. Chanthy’s mother will use $250 of the loan to purchase seed, fertilizer, and pesticide to maintain her farm, and another $250 to buy a water-pumping machine.

loans.use: To provide capital for her mother’s farming business.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph, age 54, is a farmer from Murang'a town in central Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for ten years now and employs five casual laborers. He sells his horticultural products to the local market. He is the married father of three grown children. 

He has requested a loan of 40,000 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase a water pump and irrigation pipes. He says that these assets will enable him maintain his production capacity, especially during the dry season. He will therefore have stable income from which he will create more wealth to support his family. He also plans to acquire another piece of land to enable him to expand his farming activities in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump and irrigation pipes.

loans.name: Chanveasna

texts.en: Mr. Chanveasna C., age 28, has been working in a province office for almost ten years. He is now attending a university of law as well. He requests a loan of $600 to pay for his school fees and to provide capital for his mother to purchase more vegetables for resale. He is unmarried and lives with his brother, sister, and mother in a village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

loans.use: To pay for his school fees and to provide capital for his mother's vegetable vending business

loans.name: Seun

texts.en:
Mrs. Seun Sang (pictured) and her husband, Mr. Nem Preum, live on an Island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have seven children: five sons and two daughters. Seun is a silk weaver. She also taught her daughters these skills and transferred her loom to her daughters. Her husband is a builder of wooden houses. 

Seun is requesting her second Kiva loan in the amount of $1,100, which she will use to repair the house where she and her family live.

loans.use: To repair the house where family lives

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
Joshua is a farmer from the town of Murang'a in central Kenya. He has been in the farming business for 20 years and employs three casual laborers. He also earns income from his business of buying and selling horticultural products at the local market. Joshua is 41 years old and married with three school-aged children who all attend school.

He has requested a loan of 40,000 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo in order to buy a water pump and irrigation pipes. He says that these assets will help increase his productivity and that this will earn him more income, which he will use toward educating his children. His biggest challenges have been low market prices for his products and the high cost of transportation.

loans.use: To buy a water pump and irrigation pipes.

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Un B., age 37, is a fish vendor. She sells small quantities of fish in and around the province of Kompong Tom province. This is a business she has operated for more than ten years. Un B. buys her fish from a wholesale supplier. She usually earns a profit of approximately $1.30 per day to help support her family’s expenses. The family has another financial source in her husband, who works in the farming business. 

Un B. currently uses an old motorcycle for collecting her fish from the supplier, but it is in disrepair and presently inoperable. She has spent considerable amounts of money on repairs. In order to deal with this problem, Un B. is asking for a loan from Kiva to buy a used motorcycle to replacing the broken one.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle to replace the broken one that she used to use for transporting her fish from the supplier

loans.name: Jemimah Wangui

texts.en:
Jemimah Wangui N. is 37 years old and is married to Thomas N.. Together they have three children. She runs a boutique in Lodwar town and has been in this business for four years. She makes a monthly income of KES 10,300.

This will be Jemimah's first loan from KADET LTD, and she has never borrowed from any other MFI. She plans to use the entire loan to buy new clothes for resale. With the extra income from this investment she wants to rent a bigger shop in which to sell her clothes.

In the future she wants to be financially stable and to provide for her family's basic needs, such as food, shelter and clothing.

loans.use: To buy new clothes for resale

loans.name: Joyce Alimlim

texts.en:
Joyce Alimlim N. is 30 years old and married to Dan Emuria. Together they have three children. They live in Napetet in the outskirts of Lodwar town and Joyce runs a retail shop in the same area. Joyce has been in this business for three years now and makes a monthly income of KES 15,000.

This will be Joyce's first loan from KADET LTD. She plans to use the entire loan to add stocks of rice, sugar, soft drinks etc. to her shop. In the future she would like to excel in business.

loans.use: To buy stocks of sugar, rice and cooking fat for resale

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, age 49, has been practicing mixed farming for the last five years and employs four casual laborers. He also runs a laundry business in Murang'a town in central Kenya. He is the divorced father of three children who are all adults. 

He has requested a loan of 40,000 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase a water pump and irrigation pipes. The proceeds from this project will enable him to improve his family's livelihood. He plans to expand his businesses in future and, if possible, to export his products to other markets.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump and irrigation pipes.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Your work is your integrity, whether it is something others will pay for or something you give to them for free. Marilou knows this and integrates this truth in her business. Marilou finished high school and is married to Jaime, who works as a driver. They have three children who are all in elementary school.

Toy re-packing for giveaway purposes is Marilou’s business. She re-packs toys bought wholesale and designs them as giveaway products for various occasions. Per primary customers are event organizers. She then sees to it that her products will be something her customers will be proud to give to the guests at their events. Also, Marilou makes bags and sells them at an affordable prices. With these businesses, she earns around Php 11,600 monthly.

To help her continue operation of her business, she would like to apply for a Php 10,000 loan. She will use this money to improve her product, particularly to buy materials that are of good quality.

Marilou is firm in her decision to make her business a success. With that goal in mind, she aims to create products that are nothing less than the highest possible quality. When it comes to her family, her simplest pleasure is to see them happy and not lacking in anything.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To improve her product offerings of giveaway products and to buy high-quality materials for her bag-making business

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Long H. , age 38, is a married villager living in a medium-sized home with her family members in Kompong Tom province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops. Her husband is a fisherman who fishes along the river, earning approximately $2 USD per day. 

The couple has five children: two are sewing workers, one is a grocery seller, and one is not yet working. She hopes to help her child obtain work, but she has no cash to help make that possible. She would therefore like to request a loan in order to purchase a machine for squeezing sugar cane, which she will give to her child to start a business selling sugar cane juice.

loans.use: To purchase a machine for squeezing sugar cane, which she will give to her child to start a business selling sugar cane juice.

loans.name: Mira

texts.en: Mira L., 45, believes that she has what it takes to become a successful microentrepreneur. She only reached high school, but with the determination she has to succeed, her poor educational background doesn't matter much. Mira is married to a driver named Benjamin and together they raise two children. One child is already in college, while the other is in elementary school.They live in Paliparan Site, Dasmariñas, Cavite. Running a sari-sari (variety store) is what occupies Mira's daily schedule. She determines which retail items are most needed and wanted by her community and buys them at the local market. She displays them on her store shelves in a way that will immediately get the attention of people in her neighborhood who might need a sachet of shampoo or a bottle of vinegar just to keep going with their busy lives. Aside from her sari-sari store and Benjamin's jeepney operation, they also raise pigs to meet the family's needs. Monthly, they earn around 10,380 Philippine pesos (PHP). To help expand her sari-sari store, Mira applied for a loan of 8,000 PHP. She plans to use this money to purchase more retail items such as canned goods, detergents and instant noodles among other things. With this loan, she will make sure that her store will be capable of meeting the immediate needs of her community. Mira hopes to see her small store grow into a grocery. Therefore, she goes all out to address her challenges and become a better entrepreneur. She wants to achieve this, because her main goal is to be able to support her family and assure them of a bright future. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives. * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To add quantities of retail items to her store

loans.name: Carmelita's Group

texts.en: Carmelita B. runs a general store selling both food and daily use products in her community. She is 44 years old, married and has four school-aged children. They are from the village of San Pablo Proper, Cauayan City, Isabela. Carmelita has been in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2007, Carmelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her third loan from ASKI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. Carmelita is the leader of a four member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

location.town: San Pablo Proper, Cauayan City, Isabela

loans.name: Koy

texts.en:
Koy P. has been a farming businesswoman for a long time. She lives in the province of Kompong Tom. Since 1998, Koy P. has owned and operated her farm to cultivate a rice crop, from which she makes a profit.   Koy P. is married to Mr. Hout Phorn, age 40, who is a fisherman.  Koy P. has three children, two of whom are learning in the local school, and one at home depends on her care.  

Recently, her family has been facing difficulty with their living conditions because their house needs repairs. To solve the problem, Koy P. would like a loan to purchase wood in order to repair a part of her broken house.

loans.use: To purchase wood in order to repair a part of her broken house.

loans.name: Sicily

texts.en:
Sicily is 30 years old and a single mother of one child, age 8, who attends school. She has been farming for three years and employs 2 to 3 farmhands. She also sells rice to the local market.

Sicily has requested this loan of 50,000Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase irrigation pipes and a water pump. The extra income from this loan will help her educate her child and improve their livelihood. She says that her major challenges have been lack of enough water and unpredictable weather which affects her production. She plans to acquire more land in the future to enable her to do extensive farming on a large scale.

loans.use: To purchase irrigation pipes and a water pump.

loans.name: Cipriana

texts.en:
When it comes to improving her efforts to reach her goals, for Cipriana Casa, 41, there are no holds barred. Cipriana constantly improves and rises up to her business needs as well as to her relationship with her family. She is the wife of Teodoro, who is also in business, and the mother of two children, one who studies in high school and one who is in elementary school.  Together they live in Carissa Homes, Tanza, Cavite.

Cipriana runs both an electronic shop and a sari-sari (variety) store located near their home. The electronic shop serves as her primary business.  In it she offers repair services for broken televisions and DVD’s to her neighborhood . Cipriana has been in business for nine year now. With these entrepreneurial efforts she earns Php13,960 on average per month.

To help her grow her business, she decided on a loan of Php10, 000.  For her this is a way to improve her business. With this money on hand, she can purchase spare parts of television sets and DVD’s, which are much needed in her shop. She believes that a complete set of materials is what she needs to improve her shop, and it will also eventually help her sustain their family’s needs.

Increased fares and higher prices of spare parts are the main challenges Cipriana combats at present. She also struggles with the poor health of the family. But she faces these challenges head on, knowing that she has what it takes to succeed, all the more with the Lord  ready to back her up. She hopes to become stable in terms of her business capital, in order to be able to sustain the studies of her two dear children.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy spare parts of televisions and DVD’s

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna M., 44, has got big dreams, and she’s working out her entrepreneurial capabilities to reach them. Lorna graduated from college and is now raising a family with two children, hand in hand with her husband, Michael. They currently live in Tanza, Cavite.

The main business Lorna manages is selling slippers. Also, she is into direct selling of products from beauty brands, like Avon and Natasha. She has been keeping her merchandise at home and sometimes brings them over to her customers’ houses so that they can have a good pick of what suits their taste. Lorna knows the tastes of her regular customers well, having been nine years in this business. Monthly, she is able to earn around Php10,000.

To help her continue operation of her businesses, she is requesting a Php18,000 loan. She plans to buy assorted slippers in bulk so that she can offer various options to her customers. She will also use part of the money for the renovation of their house and the studies of her children, while making sure the business stays profitable.

At present, Lorna faces problems in her family. Nevertheless, her strength comes from the time she spends praying to the Lord. She knows that if she can endure, she will emerge victorious, as the Word of the Lord says. Lorna sees that part of the victory the Lord will give her is a commercial space in a mall, where potential buyers are close at hand. She hopes for increased profitability so that, in the end, she will be able to help others in need. That, for her, is one big dream she is ready to fulfill.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase quantities of assorted slippers

loans.name: Samuel Miri

texts.en:
Samuel has practised farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last five years. He is 42 years old and married to Rose Njeri. Together they have two children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his third loan. He paid  all his previous loans in full and in good time. He plans to use the loan to buy fertilizer and seedlings for planting.

In the future Samuel hopes to become a leading farmer in Ndunyu Njeru town.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seedlings for planting

loans.name: Michael Mwai

texts.en:
Michael is 32 years old and has practised farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 10 years. He practises mixed farming, keeping dairy cows and also planting potatoes.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his third loan. He repaid all his previous loans in full and in good time. He plans to use this loan to buy a dairy cow, fertilizer and seedlings for planting.

In the future Michael hopes to practise large scale farming.

loans.use: To  buy a dairy cow, fertilizer and seedlings for planting

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Sustainability is one crucial part of a business, and it definitely matters to Carmen L., 61, not just in her business but also in her family life. Carmen is married to Francisco, and together they are raising a big family of eight children. Just like Carmen, Francisco is also a vendor. They currently live in Tanza, Cavite.

Carmen is a vegetable vendor offering fresh food options for her fellow community members who have the time to cook their own food at home. Having been four years in business, she knows which kinds are appealing, and which vegetables rarely sell. She also applies her learning from CCT* to her business, and earns around Php12, 880 monthly.

To help her grow her business, she decided on a loan amount of Php8, 000. She intends to use this money to buy more fresh vegetables, such as sweet potatoes, beans, and okra.  Other items for purchase are onions, garlic, and ginger. 

One challenge Carmen faces is the unstable prices of vegetables, which greatly affects her business. Also, she finds it hard to sustain her business capital. Nevertheless, she is on the lookout for solutions to these dilemmas and will see to it that her business will become sustainable. She hopes to be able to save up for emergency purposes, and to be able to further improve her business. Basically, all of these represent her effort to make sure that she will be able to sustain her family’s daily living and support them in reaching for their dreams.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase  quantities of fresh vegetables

loans.name: Jane Gathoni

texts.en:
Jane has run her private Kindergarten in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last four years. She is 38 years old, married to Julius Kinyua, and the mother of one child. Jane was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend, and this will be her third loan. She repaid her previous loans well within their terms, and she plans to use the loan to buy materials to finish a block of classrooms she is building.

In the future, Jane hopes to expand her Kindergarten into a primary school.

loans.use: To buy materials to finish a block of classrooms she is building.

loans.name: Nancy Nduta

texts.en:
Nancy has practised farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 10 years. She is 48 years old and married to Sammy K.. Together they have two children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers and this will be her third loan. She repaid all her previous loans in full and in good time.  She plans to use the loan to buy seedlings and fertilizer.

In the future Nancy hopes to buy more land and to practise large scale farming.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Sewing clothes is the main part of 27-year-old Sin C.’s daily duties in the garment industry. Sin C. has been engaged in her job since 2000 and has a formal salary. She has a life partner in her husband who works in the farm field. The couple helps each other to earn money to feed their one child, who is not attending school yet. Sin C. is concerned because she bought a piece of farmland from her neighbor and paid for 30 percent of the total amount, with the remaining cash on credit. Since her current savings account is not enough to pay the credit back, Sin C. is seeking a loan from Kiva through HKL. Sin C. and her old mother show in the photo.

loans.use: To pay for previously purchased farmland

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.en:
Bernardo O. is from the village of Landing, Baliangao. He is 66 years old. Bernardo is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Bernardo owns and operates a fishing venture in the food sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Bernardo has been engaged in his business for more than 30 years and earns a monthly net income of 6000.

In 2004, Bernardo joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bernardo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Bernardo is requesting his 13th loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing materials.  

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing materials

loans.name: Chom

texts.en: The young woman in the photograph is Chom Y., age 36. Chom lives in the province of Kompong Cham, which is the best territory for farming. Chom Y. is a married woman who is devoted to her husband. She has three children who are employed in various jobs. They always contribute their profit to Chom Y. so that she can use it for daily expenses. Chom Y. is not comfortable because her house often needs to be repaired. She would like a loan to buy wood for mending her old house. She will use the remainder of the loan along with her savings to buy a secondhand motorcycle for her employed children so they can ride it to where they work.

loans.use: To buy wood for home repairs and to buy a used motorcycle for her children to ride to work

loans.name: Teodosia

texts.en:
Teodosia G.'s main source of income comes from running a general store selling different products in her community. She is 59 years old, married and has two grown-up children. She is from the village of Birayan, Rizal. Teodosia has been in her business for 20 years and earns a monthly net income of 5,000.

In 2008, Teodosia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Teodosia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC which was used for her business. Teodosia is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase housing materials. This will be her seventh loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase housing materials

loans.name: Roel

texts.en: Roel G. owns and operates a general store selling assorted products in his community. He is 39 years old, married and has two school-aged children. They are from the village of Tugas, Baliangao. Roel has been managing his business for five years earns a monthly net income of 8,500. In 2011, Roel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Roel is requesting his first loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock for his store. He plans to use additional income to improve the general living conditions of his family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for his store

loans.name: Violita's Group

texts.en:
Violita O., from the village of Poblacion, Sibutad, is the 32-year-old group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Violita, who is married and has two school-aged children, owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling "puto" and other delicacies in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 11 years, she earns approximately 3,100 PHP a month.

In 2010, Violita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 3000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make puto, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to support her family needs.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make "puto"

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica N. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Zanna in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. Jessica has a tailoring business, which she has run for two years.
To help expand her business, Jessica has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase another electric sewing machine. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Jessica hopes to generate greater profits, buy clothes for her children and provide for some other basic needs at home. In the future, she hopes to expand her business into a training center.
Jessica is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her secure start-up capital to buy her first sewing machine. She is now going to buy a second machine with her second loan.

loans.use: To purchase another electric sewing machine

loans.name: Komiljon

texts.ru: Норбеков Комилчон поживает в Гиссарском районе. Ему 40 лет. Женат. Имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам он имеет средне - специальное образование, товаровед. По специальности проработал пять лет. Сейчас он занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет участок земли, где выращивает овощи и сажает фруктовые деревья. Этим видом деятельности он занимается 15 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян и топлива.
texts.en: Komiljon N. lives in the Gissar Region. He is married and has four children. His wife is a homemaker. Komiljon has a technical degree as a retail store buyer. He has worked in his specialty for five years. At present he  grows produce. He has a land plot near his house, were he grows vegetables and plants fruit trees. He has been in this line of work for 15 years. He is taking out a loan to purchase seeds and fuel.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fuel
